Practical 2: Normal data

VIBASS

Source: vignettes/p2normal.Rmd
p2normal.Rmd

How tall the VIBASS‚Äô participants are?

One of the most commonly used examples of Normal data are heights and weights. We want to continue this tradition. We will dedicate this practice to work with the heights of the VIBASS participants of the past editions. We start first with the height of the women.

Some VIBASS‚Äô participants.

Bayesian inference for the mean height of the women VIBASS‚Äô participants. The variance of the sampling Normal model is known.

The data

We have the following height data, in metres, for a random sample of n=15n=15 women participants from previous editions of VIBASS.

hwomen <- data.frame(height = c(1.73, 1.65, 1.65, 1.76, 1.65, 1.63, 1.70, 1.58, 1.57, 1.65, 1.74, 1.68, 1.67, 1.58, 1.66))

We can summarize the data and represent them by means of a histogram.

summary_table(
  mean = mean(hwomen$height),
  var = var(hwomen$height),
  quant = quantile(hwomen$height, probs = c(0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1)),
  label = "Women height",
  digits = 3
)
Summary Women height
Mean 1.660
Var 0.003
S.Dev 0.057
Min. 1.570
Q25 1.640
Q50 1.650
Q75 1.690
Max. 1.760 
hist(hwomen$height,
     main = NULL, xlab="Height in metres",
     col="gray89", xlim=c(1.50, 1.85)
)

The histogram obtained does not remind us much of the Normal distribution. But we know that when we work with small amounts of data, even if they are Normal, we cannot expect their histogram to look like a symmetrical bell. In fact, if we were to generate small Normal data samples, few of them would resemble the Gaussian ideal.

The sampling model is approximately Normal

Let YY be the random variable that describes the height of the women in VIBASS. We assume that given the mean of the height of the VIBASS women Œº\mu, the distribution of YY is Normal with mean Œº\mu and standard deviation œÉ=0.1\sigma= 0.1.

Y‚à£Œº‚àºùí©(Œº,œÉ=0.1),Y \mid \mu \sim \mathcal{N}(\mu,\, \sigma = 0.1), whose conditional density function, expectation and variance are:

  • f(y‚à£Œº)=10.12œÄe{‚àí12‚ãÖ0.12(y‚àíŒº)2}f(y \mid \mu )= \frac{1}{0.1 \,\sqrt{2 \pi}}\, \mbox{e}^{\big\{ \frac{-1}{2 \,\cdot \, 0.1^2}\,(y-\mu)^2\big\}}
  • E(Y‚à£Œº)=Œº\text{E}(Y \mid \mu)= \mu,
  • Var(Y‚à£Œº)=œÉ2=0.01.\text{Var}(Y \mid \mu) = \sigma^2 = 0.01.

A prior distribution for Œº\mu

Recall that the Normal distribution is conjugate with respect to the Normal probability model with œÉ\sigma known. If we elicit a Normal prior distribution ùí©(Œº0,œÉ0)\mathcal{N}(\mu_0,\, \sigma_0) for Œº\mu, its density is

œÄ(Œº)=1œÉ02œÄe‚àí12œÉ02(Œº‚àíŒº0)2\pi(\mu)=\frac{1}{\sigma_0 \,\sqrt{2 \pi}}\, \mbox{e}^{\, \frac{-1}{2\sigma_{0}^2}\,(\mu-\mu_0)^2 }

with prior mean and and variance

  • E(Œº)=Œº0\text{E}(\mu)= \mu_0,
  • Var(Œº)=œÉ0.\text{Var}(\mu)= \sigma_0.

We are going to work with a prior distribution based on the information from two of the VIBASS lecturers. This prior distribution is

œÄ(Œº)=ùí©(Œº0=1.70,œÉ0=0.07).\pi(\mu) = \mathcal{N}(\mu_0=1.70,\, \sigma_0=0.07).

On the basis of this distribution these two teachers think that the mean of the height of women VIBASS participants is centred on 1.701.70 m with a standard deviation of 0.070.07 m. According to it, we can compute the following percentile and probabilities

qnorm(c(0.005, 0.995), 1.70, 0.07)
#> [1] 1.519692 1.880308
pnorm(c(1.50, 1.60, 1.70, 1.80, 1.90), 1.70, 0.07)
#> [1] 0.002137367 0.076563726 0.500000000 0.923436274 0.997862633

Consequently, a 99%\% credible interval for Œº\mu is (1.52,1.88)(1.52, \,1.88) which means that the probability that a VIBASS participant is neither taller than 1.88 metres nor shorter than 1.52 is 0.99. The probability that she is shorter than 1.50 is 0.0021, the probability that her height is between 1.60 and 1.80 is 0.9234-0.0766= 0.8468 or the probability that is taller than 1.80 is 1-0.9234=0.0766. Next we show the graphic of the density of this prior distribution.

cap <- "Prior distribution for the mean height."
m0 <- 1.7; s0 <- 0.07
curve(
  dnorm(x, m0, s0),
  xlab = expression(paste(mu)), ylab = "prior",
  xlim = c(1.40, 2), lwd = 4, col = "dodgerblue", yaxt = "n"
)

Prior distribution for the mean height.

The likelihood function of Œº\mu

The likelihood is a function of Œº\mu for the data ùíü={y1,y2,‚Ä¶,y15}\mathcal D=\{y_1, y_2,\ldots, y_{15} \}. It is defined as follows

L(Œº‚à£ùíü)=f(y1,y2,‚Ä¶,y15‚à£Œº)=‚àèi=115f(yi‚à£Œº)=‚àèi=11510.12œÄexp{‚àí12‚ãÖ0.12(yi‚àíŒº)2}=1(0.1‚ãÖ2œÄ)15exp{‚àí12‚ãÖ0.12‚àëi=115(yi‚àíŒº)2}=1(0.1‚ãÖ2œÄ)15exp{‚àí12‚ãÖ0.12(‚àëi=115yi2‚àí2‚ãÖ15y‚ÄæŒº+15Œº2)}\begin{align*} L(\mu \mid \mathcal D)=& f(y_1, y_2, \ldots, y_{15} \mid \mu) = \prod_{i=1}^{15}\, f(y_i \mid \mu) = \prod_{i=1}^{15}\, \frac{1}{0.1\,\sqrt{2 \pi}}\, \exp\Big\{\, \frac{-1}{2 \cdot 0.1^2}\,(y_i-\mu)^2\Big\} \\ = & \, \frac{1}{(0.1\,\cdot\sqrt{2 \pi})^{15}}\,\,\exp\Big\{\, \frac{-1}{2 \cdot 0.1^2}\,\sum_{i=1}^{15}\,(y_i-\mu)^2\Big \} \\ = &\,\frac{1}{(0.1\,\cdot\sqrt{2 \pi})^{15}}\,\,\exp\Big\{\, \frac{-1}{2 \cdot 0.1^2}\,\Big(\sum_{i=1}^{15} y_i^{2} - 2 \cdot 15 \, \bar{y} \, \mu + 15 \mu^2\Big)\Big \} \end{align*}

where f(y1,y2,‚Ä¶,y15‚à£Œº)f(y_1, y_2, \ldots, y_{15} \mid \mu) is the joint density of the YiY_i‚Äôs given Œº\mu evaluated in ùíü\mathcal D. Since the YiY_i‚Äôs are conditionally independent given Œº\mu, the joint density is the product of the marginal densities. In our case, the likelihood function of Œº\mu is

cap <- "Likelihood function."
Lnorm <- function(mu, y, sigma) {
  # Essentially:
  # prod(dnorm(y, mean = mu, sd = sigma))
  # but we make it numerically more stable working on the log scale
  # and we vectorise over mu
  vapply(
    mu,
    function(.) exp(sum(dnorm(y, mean = ., sd = sigma, log = TRUE))),
    1
  )
}
curve(
  Lnorm(x, hwomen$height, 0.1),
  xlab = expression(paste(mu)), ylab = "likelihood", 
  xlim = c(1.4, 2), col = "darkorange", lwd = 4, yaxt = "n"
)

Likelihood function.

The posterior distribution of Œº\mu

The posterior distribution of Œº\mu is a Normal distribution with parameters

œÄ(Œº‚à£ùíü)=ùí©(Œºn,œÉn),whereœÉn2=œÉ02œÉ2œÉ2+nœÉ02=0.072‚ãÖ0.120.12+15‚ãÖ0.072=0.000587,‚§≥œÉn=0.0242Œºn=œÉn2(Œº0œÉ02+ny‚ÄæœÉ2)=0.000587(1.700.072+15‚ãÖ1.660.12)=1.6648\begin{align*} \pi(\mu \mid \mathcal{D}) & = \mathcal{N}(\mu_n,\, \sigma_n), \, \text{where}\\ \sigma^2_n & =\frac{\sigma_0^2\,\sigma^2}{\sigma^2 + n \,\sigma_0^2}= \frac{0.07^2 \cdot 0.1^2}{0.1^2 + 15 \cdot 0.07^2}= 0.000587, \leadsto \sigma_n=0.0242\\ \mu_n & = \sigma_n^2 \,\Big (\frac{\mu_0}{\sigma_0^2}\, + \, \frac{n \bar{y}}{\sigma^2}\Big) = 0.000587 \Big(\frac{1.70}{0.07^2} +\frac{15 \cdot 1.66}{0.1^2}\Big) = 1.6648 \end{align*}

Next, we plot on the same graph the prior (in blue) and the posterior distribution (in green) of Œº\muœÄ(Œº)=ùí©(Œº0=1.70,œÉ0=0.07)œÄ(Œº‚à£ùíü)=ùí©(Œºn=1.6648,œÉn=0.0242)\begin{align*} \pi(\mu &)=\mathcal{N}(\mu_0=1.70, \sigma_0=0.07)\\ \pi(\mu &\mid \mathcal D)=\mathcal{N}(\mu_n=1.6648, \sigma_n=0.0242) \end{align*}

m0 <- 1.7; s0 <- 0.07
m1 <- 1.6648; s1 <- 0.0242
curve(
  dnorm(x, m1, s1),
  xlab = expression(paste(mu)), ylab = "density",
  xlim = c(1.40, 2), lwd = 4, col = "darkgreen", yaxt = "n"
)
curve(
  dnorm(x, m0, s0),
  lwd = 4, col = "dodgerblue", add = TRUE
)

Prior (blue) and posterior (green) distributions for the mean height.

The visual difference between the two distributions is very clear: The posterior distribution has a very low variability compared to the prior (œÉn‚âà0.02\sigma_n \approx 0.02 m vs.¬†œÉ0=0.07\sigma_0 =0.07 m) and is slightly shifted to the left because the posterior mean is slightly lower than the prior mean (Œºn‚âà1.7\mu_n\approx 1.7 vs.¬†Œº0=1.7\mu_0 = 1.7).

On the basis of the posterior distribution, the two teachers now think that the mean of the height of women VIBASS participants is centred on Œºn\mu_n with a standard deviation of œÉn\sigma_n metres. According to it, we can compute the following percentiles and probabilities

qnorm(c(0.005, 0.995), m1, s1)
#> [1] 1.602465 1.727135
pnorm(c(1.50, 1.60, 1.70, 1.80, 1.90), m1, s1)
#> [1] 4.882741e-12 3.706635e-03 9.271024e-01 1.000000e+00 1.000000e+00

Consequently, a 99% credible interval for Œº\mu is (1.6,1.73)(1.6, 1.73), which means that the probability that a VIBASS participant is between 1.6 m and 1.73 m is 0.99. The probability that she is shorter than 1.50 m is 0.00000.0000, the probability that her height is between 1.60 m and 1.80 m is 1.0000‚àí0.0040=0.99601.0000-0.0040=0.9960 or the probability that is taller than 1.80 m is 0.0000.

The posterior predictive distribution for the height of a new VIBASS participant

We are interested in predicting the height of Anin√®, a new female VIBASS participant who has not participated in the sample of the inferential process. In this case, the posterior predictive distribution for the Anin√®‚Äôs height Y16Y_{16} is a Normal distribution

ùí©(Œºn,œÉn2+œÉ2)\mathcal{N}\Big(\mu_n, \sqrt{\sigma_n^2+\sigma^2}\Big)

with standard deviation œÉn2+œÉ2=0.000587+0.01=0.1029\sqrt{\sigma_n^2+\sigma^2} = \sqrt{0.000587+0.01}=0.1029.

It is important to note that the mean of this predictive distribution coincides with the mean of the posterior distribution of Œº\mu. However, the enormous variability of the predictive distribution, which depends on the variability of the sampling model and the variability of the a posteriori distribution, is very striking. The following figure shows the posterior distribution (in green) of Œº\mu and the posterior predictive distribution (in purple) for Anin√®‚Äôs height illustrating the previous comments.

mp <- m1; sp <- sqrt(s1^2 + 0.1^2)
curve(
  dnorm(x, m1, s1),
  xlab = expression(paste(mu)), ylab = "density",
  xlim = c(1.40, 2), lwd = 4, col = "darkgreen", yaxt = "n"
)
curve(
  dnorm(x, mp, sp),
  lwd = 4, col = "purple", add = TRUE
)

Predictive (purple) and posterior (green) distributions for the mean height.

We can calculate prediction intervals for the height of Anin√®. A prediction interval at 95% would be

qnorm(c(0.025, 0.975), 1.6642, 0.1029)
#> [1] 1.46252 1.86588

This indicates that the probability that Anin√®‚Äôs height is between 1.46 and 1.87 metres is 0.95.

Bayesian inference for the mean height of the women VIBASS participants. The variance of the sampling Normal model is unknown.

If we follow the same scheme as in the previous case where the variance was known, we would have a first section dedicated to the data which would be the same. The sampling model is also approximately Normal but now we will work with a Normal with unknown mean and variance.

The sampling model is approximately Normal

Let YY the random variable that describes the height of the women in VIBASS. We assume that the distribution of YY is Normal with unknown mean Œº\mu and unknown standard deviation œÉ\sigma

Y‚à£Œº‚àºùí©(Œº,œÉ),Y \mid \mu \sim \mathcal{N}(\mu,\, \sigma), whose conditional density function, expectation and variance are:

  • f(y‚à£Œº)=1œÉ2œÄe{‚àí12(y‚àíŒºœÉ)2}f(y \mid \mu )= \frac{1}{\sigma \,\sqrt{2 \pi}}\, \mbox{e}^{\big\{ -\frac12 \big(\frac{y-\mu}{\sigma}\big)^2\big\}}
  • E(Y‚à£Œº)=Œº\text{E}(Y\mid \mu)= \mu,
  • Var(Y‚à£Œº)=œÉ2.\text{Var}(Y\mid \mu)=\sigma^2.

A prior distribution for (Œº,œÉ2)(\mu,\, \sigma^2)

Our basic quantity of interest is bi-dimensional (Œº,œÉ2)(\mu,\, \sigma^2). We work in a non-informative prior scenario and use the improper reference prior distribution

œÄ(Œº,œÉ2)‚àù1/œÉ2\pi(\mu,\, \sigma^2) \propto 1/\sigma^2

The likelihood function of (Œº,œÉ2)(\mu,\, \sigma^2)

The likelihood is a function of (Œº,œÉ2)(\mu,\, \sigma^2) for the data ùíü={y1,y2,‚Ä¶,y15}\mathcal D=\{y_1, y_2,\ldots, y_{15} \}. It is defined as follows

L(Œº,œÉ2‚à£ùíü)=f(y1,y2,‚Ä¶,y15‚à£Œº,œÉ2)=‚àèi=115f(yi‚à£Œº,œÉ2)=‚àèi=1151œÉ2œÄexp{‚àí12œÉ2(yi‚àíŒº)2}=1(œÉ2œÄ)15exp{‚àí12œÉ2‚àëi=115(yi‚àíŒº)2}=1(œÉ2œÄ)15exp{‚àí12œÉ2(‚àëi=115yi2‚àí2‚ãÖ15y‚ÄæŒº+15Œº2)},\begin{align*} L(\mu,\, \sigma^2 \mid \mathcal D)=& f(y_1, y_2, \ldots, y_{15} \mid \mu,\, \sigma^2) = \prod_{i=1}^{15}\, f(y_i \mid \mu,\, \sigma^2) = \prod_{i=1}^{15}\, \frac{1}{\sigma \,\sqrt{2 \pi}}\, \exp\Big\{\, \frac{-1}{2\sigma^2}\,(y_i-\mu)^2\Big\} \\ = & \, \frac{1}{(\sigma\,\sqrt{2 \pi})^{15}}\,\,\exp\Big\{\, \frac{-1}{2\sigma^2}\,\sum_{i=1}^{15}\,(y_i-\mu)^2\Big \} \\ = &\,\frac{1}{(\sigma\,\sqrt{2 \pi})^{15}}\,\,\exp\Big\{\, \frac{-1}{2 \sigma^2}\,\big( \sum_{i=1}^{15} y_i^{2} - 2 \cdot 15 \, \bar{y} \, \mu + 15 \mu^2 \big) \Big\}, \end{align*}

where f(y1,y2,‚Ä¶,y15)f(y_1, y_2, \ldots, y_{15}) is the joint density of the YiY_i‚Äôs given Œº\mu and œÉ2\sigma^2 evaluated in ùíü\mathcal D. Since YiY_i‚Äôs are independent given Œº\mu and œÉ2\sigma^2, the joint density is the product of the marginal densities. In our case, the graphic of the likelihood function of (Œº,œÉ2)(\mu,\, \sigma^2) will be

The posterior distribution of (Œº,œÉ2)(\mu,\, \sigma^2)

The posterior distribution of (Œº,œÉ2)(\mu,\, \sigma^2) is a bivariant probability distribution whose joint posterior density function can be expressed in terms of the conditional posterior distribution of Œº\mu given œÉ2\sigma^2 and the marginal posterior distribution of œÉ2\sigma^2 as follows

œÄ(Œº,œÉ2‚à£ùíü)=œÄ(Œº‚à£œÉ2,ùíü)œÄ(œÉ2‚à£ùíü), \pi(\mu, \sigma^2 \mid \mathcal{D}) = \pi(\mu \mid \sigma^2, \mathcal{D}) \, \pi(\sigma^2 \mid \mathcal{D}),

where

  • œÄ(Œº‚à£œÉ2,ùíü)=ùí©(Œºn,œÉn2=œÉ2/15)\pi(\mu \mid \sigma^2, \mathcal D) =\mathcal{N}(\mu_n, \sigma^2_n = \sigma^2/15)

  • œÄ(œÉ2‚à£ùíü)\pi(\sigma^2 \mid \mathcal D) is such that œÄ((n‚àí1)s2/œÉ2‚à£ùíü)=œá2(n‚àí1)\pi((n-1)s^2/\sigma^2 \mid \mathcal D) = \chi^2(n-1), where s2=‚àë(yi‚àíy‚Äæ)2/(n‚àí1)s^2 = \sum(y_i - \bar{y})^2 / (n-1)

  • The posterior marginal of Œº\mu is œÄ(Œº‚à£ùíü)=St(y‚Äæ,s2/n,n‚àí1)\pi(\mu \mid \mathcal D)= \text{St}(\bar{y}, s^2/n, n-1)

In our case, the more relevant posterior distributions are the marginal ones:

  • The posterior marginal œÄ(œÉ2‚à£ùíü)\pi(\sigma^2 \mid \mathcal D) is such that œÄ(0.045598/œÉ2‚à£ùíü)=œá2(14)\pi(0.045598/\sigma^2 \mid \mathcal D) = \chi^2(14)

  • The posterior marginal of œÄ(Œº‚à£ùíü)=St(1.66,0.003257/15=0.000217,14)\pi(\mu \mid \mathcal D)= \text{St}(1.66, 0.003257/15=0.000217, 14)

We start working with the posterior œÄ(Œº‚à£ùíü)\pi(\mu \mid \mathcal D). The posterior mean and scale of Œº\mu are y‚Äæ=1.66\bar{y} = 1.66 and s2/n=0.014735\sqrt{s^2/n} = 0.014735 m. A 99%\% credible interval for Œº\mu is (1.62,1.70)(1.62, 1.70) and the posterior probabilities that the mean of the height of the women VIBASS is less than 1.50,1.60.1.70,1.80,and 1.901.50, 1.60. 1.70, 1.80, \text{and } 1.90 are 0.0000,0.0006,0.9916,1.0000,and 1.00000.0000, 0.0006, 0.9916, 1.0000, \text{and } 1.0000, respectively.

ny <- length(hwomen$height)
ybar <- mean(hwomen$height)
s2 <- sum((hwomen$height - ybar) ** 2) / (ny - 1)

post_mu <- list(
  mean = ybar,
  scale = sqrt(s2 / ny)
)
post_mu$scale * qt(c(0.005, 0.995), ny - 1) + post_mu$mean
#> [1] 1.616134 1.703866
pt((c(1.50, 1.60, 1.70, 1.80, 1.90) - post_mu$mean) / post_mu$scale, ny - 1)
#> [1] 1.669533e-08 5.718022e-04 9.916131e-01 9.999999e-01 1.000000e+00

The graphics of that posterior density is

curve(
  dt((x - post_mu$mean) / post_mu$scale, ny - 1) / post_mu$scale,
  xlab = expression(paste(mu)), ylab = "density",
  xlim = c(1.40, 2), lwd = 4, col = "darkgreen", yaxt = "n"
)

Posterior (green) distribution for the mean height.

We focus now on the variance of the sampling model. Its posterior distribution is such that œÄ(0.045598/œÉ2‚à£ùíü)=œá2(14)\pi(0.045598/\sigma^2 \mid \mathcal D) = \chi^2(14). This is not the posterior distribution of œÉ2\sigma^2 but a function, 0.045598/œÉ20.045598/\sigma^2, of it. Consequently, we can approximate the posterior distribution for œÉ2\sigma^2 by simulation as follows:

  • If {a(1),a(2),‚Ä¶,a(M)}\{a^{(1)}, a^{(2)}, \ldots, a^{(M)}\} is a random sample from œÄ(0.045598/œÉ2‚à£ùíü)=œá2(14)\pi(0.045598/\sigma^2 \mid \mathcal D) = \chi^2(14) then {0.045598/a(1),0.045598/a(2),‚Ä¶,0.045598/a(M)}\{0.045598/a^{(1)}, 0.045598/a^{(2)}, \ldots, 0.045598/a^{(M)}\} is a random sample from œÄ(œÉ2‚à£ùíü)\pi(\sigma^2 \mid \mathcal D).

Next we show the approximate graph and some posterior characteristics of the posterior œÄ(œÉ2‚à£ùíü)\pi(\sigma^2 \mid \mathcal D).

y <- seq(0, 40, 0.001)
simuchi <- rchisq(y, ny - 1)
simu.sigma <- 0.045598 / simuchi 
hist(
  simu.sigma,
  breaks = 300, freq = FALSE, col = "gray99",
  xlim = c(0, 0.02), ylim = c(0, 400),
  main = NULL, ylab = "density", xlab = expression(paste(sigma2))
)


summary(simu.sigma)
#>     Min.  1st Qu.   Median     Mean  3rd Qu.     Max. 
#> 0.000904 0.002667 0.003413 0.003789 0.004466 0.026238
var(simu.sigma)
#> [1] 2.768883e-06
sqrt(var(simu.sigma))
#> [1] 0.001663996
quantile(simu.sigma, probs = c(0.005,0.995))
#>        0.5%       99.5% 
#> 0.001468482 0.010937895

We observe that E(œÉ2‚à£ùíü)=0.0038\text{E}(\sigma^2 \mid \mathcal D)=0.0038 and a 9999% credible interval for œÉ2\sigma^2 is (0.00147,0.01118)(0.00147, 0.01118).

Time to individual work

We propose below an individual exercise that pursues to consolidate the basic concepts that we have learned in the previous theoretical session and that we have been practising in this session.

Exercice

We focus now on the height of the VIBASS men participants.

hmen <- data.frame(height = c(1.92, 1.82, 1.69, 1.75, 1.72, 1.71, 1.73, 1.69, 1.70, 1.78, 1.88, 1.82, 1.86, 1.65))

  1. Construct a Bayesian inferential process for the mean of the height of the VIBASS men participants. Assume a non-informative prior scenario and a sampling model approximately Normal with

    • Known variance œÉ2=0.1\sigma^2=0.1.

    • Unknown variance.

  2. Compare the mean of the height between men and women. Is it possible to compute the posterior probability associated to Œºm‚àíŒºw\mu_\text{m}-\mu_\text{w}? and to Œºm/Œºw\mu_\text{m}/\mu_\text{w}?

Developed by VIBASS7, Facundo Mu√±oz.
